awd_titl_txt: TENNESSEE CYBERCORPS: A HYBRID PROGRAM IN CYBERSECURITY
awd_abstract_narration:
This proposal will inaugurate a CyberCorps®: Scholarship for Service (SFS) program at the Tennessee Technological University. The hybrid program, ensuring students? participation in research and outreach activities alongside education in cybersecurity, will offer both accelerated and traditional graduate studies paths to students from Tennessee as well as students from women and underrepresented minority populations across the nation. The proposed CyberCorps® is a university-wide effort leveraging resources and expertise from the Computer Science Department, Cybersecurity Education Research and Outreach Center, College of Engineering, Student Success Center, Office of Admissions, College of Graduate Studies, Library, Office of Research, and Career Services. This CyberCorps® program will be the first one in the state of Tennessee and it will have the opportunity to serve the Appalachian area in Tennessee.

The project will provide strategies and techniques that have the potential to be effective in addressing challenges associated with SFS program management. The project will take recommendations from experts based on demonstrated evidence to develop and exercise a suite of best practices for effective management of SFS program. The project will draw upon teaching, research and outreach experiences of the investigators, and the assessment experience of the evaluation specialist.

The project provides broader impact by delivering a SFS program that will lead to broader participation and better preparation of the information assurance and cybersecurity workforce. Students underrepresented in cybersecurity are a major focus of this project. As such, an expected broader impact of the project is to contribute to the ability of the United States higher education enterprise to produce a diverse group of cybersecurity professionals. As part of its broader impact, this project will contribute to the statewide effort to meet a shortage of skilled workers by having the CyberCorps scholarship opportunity accessible to first-generation/low-income community college students impacted by the TN Promise initiative. Since TTU is situated within and serves Central Appalachia, this project will have the opportunity to serve the Appalachian area in TN, which is one of the poorest regions in the country. The region also has a lower education attainment level than the country as an average.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
In 2016, Tennessee Tech University (TNTech) received a $3.95 million SFS award entitled: "Tennessee CyberCorps: A Hybrid Program in Cybersecurity". This award aimed to launch a hybrid SFS program in TNTech that supports students' participation in cybersecurity education, research, and outreach activities. Through this award, TNTech has been an SFS institution since 2016, hence, becoming the first of its kind in Tennessee. Currently, TNTech is the largest and one of two such programs in Tennessee. The following project outcomes are reported over the period 2016 - 2022.

Workforce Development of Cybersecurity Professionals:
The original target of this award was to introduce 26 workforce-ready professionals in cybersecurity. However, during the award period (2016 - 2022), this award has served a total of 38 students that have been trained in cybersecurity. Thus, the TNTech SFS program has exceeded its target by serving 146% of the proposed students. The TNTech SFS program has graduated 28 students and the remaining 10 students are being supported through a renewal of the SFS award. Of those who completed their degrees (28), 24 (86%) received an M.S. degree, 2 (7%) received a B.S. degree, 1 (3.5%) received an A.S. degree, and 1 (3.5%) received a Ph.D. degree. Since the majority of the SFS graduates (86%) hold an M.S. degree, they are qualified for the upper 20% of the cybersecurity market opportunities. All (100%) of the graduated TNTech SFS students have been successfully placed in jobs. The TNTech SFS Program does NOT have any defaulters. All TNTech SFS alums are currently working on federal and state agencies such as NSA, DHS, FBI, and national labs such as Oakridge National Lab, Los Alamos National Lab, and many more.  

Formal and Informal Education in Cybersecurity: 
All TNTech SFS students (100%) participated in formal and informal cybersecurity-related training. Formal education involves coursework in network security, cryptography, secure software development, cyber-physical system security, AI-assisted cybersecurity, cloud security, application security, etc. In addition, students participated in informal learning through cyber interest groups for defense, offense, and capture the flag (CTF). Also, all the TNTech SFS students participated in informal learning through cybersecurity competitions such as the National Cyber League, picoCTF, CyberForce, and HiveStorm. It is worth mentioning that TNTech SFS students won the third place in the Global Collegiate Penetration Testing Competition finals in 2022. Moreover, the majority of the TNTech SFS students had participated in cybersecurity conferences. Also, all of TNTech SFS students have successfully been placed in internships.

Research Experience in Cybersecurity: 
All of the TNTech SFS students participated in research through their coursework, summer internships, graduate projects, and/or faculty-sponsored projects. The research topics include cyber-physical security of critical infrastructures, smart farming, malware analysis, secure data containers, etc. As an outcome of their research work, the TNTech SFS students published more than 20 research papers in peer-reviewed conferences, journals, and book chapters.  

Outreach Activities in Cybersecurity: 
All of TNTech SFS students participated in paying it forward. The students have participated in various Computer Science on-campus student communities that include CyberEagles, ACM, ACM-W, and WiCyS Student Chapter. Several TNTech SFS students had served as mentors in the Cyber Interest groups. The TNTech SFS students have also generously volunteered in numerous off-campus events such as the GenCyber Summer Camps and Community College Outreach.

Contributions to the SFS Community 
(a) SFS Bootcamp and NS3 Seminar Series: 
As part of this award, TNTech developed training programs for new SFS students both at our university and around the country. The initial training programs were called Bootcamps and were held on the TNTech campus. In 2020, the Bootcamp went virtual due to COVID. In 2021, the program shifted to an online seminar series (NS3). Among the goals of the SFS Bootcamp was for the new students to understand the responsibilities of being an SFS scholar and learn about being a successful SFS scholar. Since it was launched in Aug. 2016, the SFS Bootcamp and the NS3 Seminar Series have served more than 500 SFS students from all around the country. The collected feedback from the participating students showed that these events helped them in networking, learning about the SFS program expectations, federal agencies, job opportunities, technical and soft skills, and internship opportunities.
(b) SFS Program Related Materials:
For the SFS cohort program, we developed a customized SFS Student Agreement for TNTech that serves as an additional contract between our students and school in addition to the general SFS OPM contract. We also developed Promissory Notes for students addressing anyone defaulting to the program. We have shared these materials upon request with various new SFS schools. 

Summary
Overall, this SFS award has met its goal in creating a hybrid SFS program in TNTech that supports students' participation in cybersecurity education, research, and outreach activities. In addition, the TNTech SFS program has contributed positively to the SFS community.


Last Modified: 11/24/2022
Modified by: Muhammad Ismail
